  16. (** Operations on file names. *)

  18. ‌val current_dir_name : string
  19. (** The conventional name for the current directory (e.g. [.] in Unix). *)

  21. ‌val parent_dir_name : string
  22. (** The conventional name for the parent of the current directory
  23.    (e.g. [..] in Unix). *)

  25. ‌val dir_sep : string
  26. (** The directory separator (e.g. [/] in Unix).

  28.     @since 3.11.2 *)

  30. ‌val concat : string -> string -> string
  31. (** [concat dir file] returns a file name that designates file
  32.    [file] in directory [dir]. *)

  34. ‌val is_relative : string -> bool
  35. (** Return [true] if the file name is relative to the current
  36.    directory, [false] if it is absolute (i.e. in Unix, starts
  37.    with [/]). *)

  39. ‌val is_implicit : string -> bool
  40. (** Return [true] if the file name is relative and does not start
  41.    with an explicit reference to the current directory ([./] or
  42.    [../] in Unix), [false] if it starts with an explicit reference
  43.    to the root directory or the current directory. *)

  45. ‌val check_suffix : string -> string -> bool
  46. (** [check_suffix name suff] returns [true] if the filename [name]
  47.     ends with the suffix [suff].

  49.     Under Windows ports (including Cygwin), comparison is
  50.     case-insensitive, relying on [String.lowercase_ascii].  Note that
  51.     this does not match exactly the interpretation of case-insensitive
  52.     filename equivalence from Windows.  *)

  54. ‌val chop_suffix : string -> string -> string
  55. (** [chop_suffix name suff] removes the suffix [suff] from
  56.     the filename [name].
  57.     @raise Invalid_argument if [name] does not end with the suffix [suff].
  58. *)

  60. ‌val chop_suffix_opt: suffix:string -> string -> string option
  61. (** [chop_suffix_opt ~suffix filename] removes the suffix from
  62.     the [filename] if possible, or returns [None] if the
  63.     filename does not end with the suffix.

  65.     Under Windows ports (including Cygwin), comparison is
  66.     case-insensitive, relying on [String.lowercase_ascii].  Note that
  67.     this does not match exactly the interpretation of case-insensitive
  68.     filename equivalence from Windows.

  70.     @since 4.08
  71. *)


  74. ‌val extension : string -> string
  75. (** [extension name] is the shortest suffix [ext] of [name0] where:

  77.     - [name0] is the longest suffix of [name] that does not
  78.       contain a directory separator;
  79.     - [ext] starts with a period;
  80.     - [ext] is preceded by at least one non-period character
  81.       in [name0].

  83.     If such a suffix does not exist, [extension name] is the empty
  84.     string.

  86.     @since 4.04
  87. *)

  89. ‌val remove_extension : string -> string
  90. (** Return the given file name without its extension, as defined
  91.     in {!Filename.extension}. If the extension is empty, the function
  92.     returns the given file name.

  94.     The following invariant holds for any file name [s]:

  96.     [remove_extension s ^ extension s = s]

  98.     @since 4.04
  99. *)

  101. ‌val chop_extension : string -> string
  102. (** Same as {!Filename.remove_extension}, but raise [Invalid_argument]
  103.     if the given name has an empty extension. *)


  106. ‌val basename : string -> string
  107. (** Split a file name into directory name / base file name.
  108.    If [name] is a valid file name, then [concat (dirname name) (basename name)]
  109.    returns a file name which is equivalent to [name]. Moreover,
  110.    after setting the current directory to [dirname name] (with {!Sys.chdir}),
  111.    references to [basename name] (which is a relative file name)
  112.    designate the same file as [name] before the call to {!Sys.chdir}.

  114.    This function conforms to the specification of POSIX.1-2008 for the
  115.    [basename] utility. *)

  117. ‌val dirname : string -> string
  118. (** See {!Filename.basename}.
  119.    This function conforms to the specification of POSIX.1-2008 for the
  120.    [dirname] utility. *)

  122. ‌val null : string
  123. (** [null] is ["/dev/null"] on POSIX and ["NUL"] on Windows. It represents a
  124.     file on the OS that discards all writes and returns end of file on reads.

  126.     @since 4.10 *)

  128. ‌val temp_file : ?temp_dir: string -> string -> string -> string
  129. (** [temp_file prefix suffix] returns the name of a
  130.    fresh temporary file in the temporary directory.
  131.    The base name of the temporary file is formed by concatenating
  132.    [prefix], then a suitably chosen integer number, then [suffix].
  133.    The optional argument [temp_dir] indicates the temporary directory
  134.    to use, defaulting to the current result of {!Filename.get_temp_dir_name}.
  135.    The temporary file is created empty, with permissions [0o600]
  136.    (readable and writable only by the file owner).  The file is
  137.    guaranteed to be different from any other file that existed when
  138.    [temp_file] was called.
  139.    @raise Sys_error if the file could not be created.
  140.    @before 3.11.2 no ?temp_dir optional argument
  141. *)

  143. ‌val open_temp_file :
  144.       ?mode: open_flag list -> ?perms: int -> ?temp_dir: string -> string ->
  145.       string -> string * out_channel
  146. (** Same as {!Filename.temp_file}, but returns both the name of a fresh
  147.    temporary file, and an output channel opened (atomically) on
  148.    this file.  This function is more secure than [temp_file]: there
  149.    is no risk that the temporary file will be modified (e.g. replaced
  150.    by a symbolic link) before the program opens it.  The optional argument
  151.    [mode] is a list of additional flags to control the opening of the file.
  152.    It can contain one or several of [Open_append], [Open_binary],
  153.    and [Open_text].  The default is [[Open_text]] (open in text mode). The
  154.    file is created with permissions [perms] (defaults to readable and
  155.    writable only by the file owner, [0o600]).

  157.    @raise Sys_error if the file could not be opened.
  158.    @before 4.03 no ?perms optional argument
  159.    @before 3.11.2 no ?temp_dir optional argument
  160. *)

  162. ‌val temp_dir : ?temp_dir: string -> ?perms:int  -> string -> string -> string
  163. (** [temp_dir prefix suffix] creates and returns the name of a fresh
  164.    temporary directory with permissions [perms] (defaults to 0o700)
  165.    inside [temp_dir].  The base name of the temporary directory is
  166.    formed by concatenating [prefix], then a suitably chosen integer
  167.    number, then [suffix].  The optional argument [temp_dir] indicates
  168.    the temporary directory to use, defaulting to the current result of
  169.    {!Filename.get_temp_dir_name}.  The temporary directory is created
  170.    empty, with permissions [0o700] (readable, writable, and searchable
  171.    only by the file owner).  The directory is guaranteed to be
  172.    different from any other directory that existed when [temp_dir] was
  173.    called.

  175.    If temp_dir does not exist, this function does not create it.  Instead,
  176.    it raises Sys_error.

  178.    @raise Sys_error if the directory could not be created.
  179.    @since 5.1
  180. *)

  182. ‌val get_temp_dir_name : unit -> string
  183. (** The name of the temporary directory:
  184.     Under Unix, the value of the [TMPDIR] environment variable, or "/tmp"
  185.     if the variable is not set.
  186.     Under Windows, the value of the [TEMP] environment variable, or "."
  187.     if the variable is not set.
  188.     The temporary directory can be changed with {!Filename.set_temp_dir_name}.
  189.     @since 4.00
  190. *)

  192. ‌val set_temp_dir_name : string -> unit
  193. (** Change the temporary directory returned by {!Filename.get_temp_dir_name}
  194.     and used by {!Filename.temp_file} and {!Filename.open_temp_file}.
  195.     The temporary directory is a domain-local value which is inherited
  196.     by child domains.
  197.     @since 4.00
  198. *)

  200. ‌val quote : string -> string
  201. (** Return a quoted version of a file name, suitable for use as
  202.     one argument in a command line, escaping all meta-characters.
  203.     Warning: under Windows, the output is only suitable for use
  204.     with programs that follow the standard Windows quoting
  205.     conventions.
  206. *)

  208. ‌val quote_command :
  209.        string -> ?stdin:string -> ?stdout:string -> ?stderr:string
  210.               -> string list -> string
  211. (** [quote_command cmd args] returns a quoted command line, suitable
  212.     for use as an argument to {!Sys.command}, {!Unix.system}, and the
  213.     {!Unix.open_process} functions.

  215.     The string [cmd] is the command to call.  The list [args] is
  216.     the list of arguments to pass to this command.  It can be empty.

  218.     The optional arguments [?stdin] and [?stdout] and [?stderr] are
  219.     file names used to redirect the standard input, the standard
  220.     output, or the standard error of the command.
  221.     If [~stdin:f] is given, a redirection [< f] is performed and the
  222.     standard input of the command reads from file [f].
  223.     If [~stdout:f] is given, a redirection [> f] is performed and the
  224.     standard output of the command is written to file [f].
  225.     If [~stderr:f] is given, a redirection [2> f] is performed and the
  226.     standard error of the command is written to file [f].
  227.     If both [~stdout:f] and [~stderr:f] are given, with the exact
  228.     same file name [f], a [2>&1] redirection is performed so that the
  229.     standard output and the standard error of the command are interleaved
  230.     and redirected to the same file [f].

  232.     Under Unix and Cygwin, the command, the arguments, and the redirections
  233.     if any are quoted using {!Filename.quote}, then concatenated.
  234.     Under Win32, additional quoting is performed as required by the
  235.     [cmd.exe] shell that is called by {!Sys.command}.
  236.     @raise Failure if the command cannot be escaped on the current platform.
  237.     @since 4.10
  238. *)

One Level Up Top Level
